title: Automated Segmentation of Kidney Nephron Structures by Deep Learning Models on Label-free Autofluorescence Microscopy for Spatial Multi-omics Data Acquisition and Mining
abstract: Automated spatial segmentation models can enrich spatio-molecular omics analyses by providing a link to relevant biological structures. We developed segmentation models that use label-free autofluorescence (AF) microscopy to recognize multicellular functional tissue units (FTUs) (glomerulus, proximal tubule, descending thin limb, ascending thick limb, distal tubule, and collecting duct) and gross morphological structures (cortex, outer medulla, and inner medulla) in human kidney. Annotations were curated using highly specific multiplex immunofluorescence and transferred to co-registered AF for model training. All FTUs (except descending thin limb) and gross kidney morphology were segmented with high accuracy: >0.85 F1-score, and Dice-Sorensen coefficients >0.80, respectively. This workflow allowed lipids, profiled by imaging mass spectrometry, to be quantitatively associated with segmented FTUs. The segmentation masks were also used to acquire spatial transcriptomics data from collecting ducts. Consistent with previous literature, we demonstrated differing transcript expression of collecting ducts in inner and outer medulla.

title: Intrinsic properties ensure reliable attractor dynamics in learned neural assemblies embedded within noisy, asynchronous networks
abstract: Neural representations rely on ability of neuronal assemblies to display organized spiking patterns, despite being embedded within noisy networks. These structured patterns arise from attractor dynamics due to activity reverberation promoted by learnt assembly connectivity. Yet, attractor dynamics have been assessed either under low-noise conditions or in highly idealized neuronal assemblies. Here, in a spiking recurrent neural network model displaying asynchronous irregular noise, we show that realistic spike timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) imposes either low controllability of attractor recall (when STDP is strong), low stability of attractor maintenance (when STDP is low), or both. Moreover, STDP-built attractors display low independence, i.e., they perturb activity in surrounding network. These constraints may favor self-generated representation switches essential for cognitive flexibility but dampening cognitive reliability. We reveal, by contrast, that several biophysical mechanisms alleviate these issues through a common dynamical principle, protecting excitatory-driven attractorial dynamics from inhibitory-driven spontaneous fluctuations. Amongst biophysical determinants, intrinsic properties were most efficient to increase controllability, stability and independence of attractor dynamics. Specifically, spike-triggered calcium-activated conductances improved reliability by mitigating reliance on connectivity, even at low conductance levels, i.e., in absence of cell-autonomous intrinsic bistability. Finally, we show that mechanisms we identify operate over a large repertoire of static (e.g., Hebbian or ring) and dynamic (e.g., sequences) attractors, with uni- and bidirectional propagation. Altogether, these results pinpoint synaptic and intrinsic synergy as a generic principle to regulate attractor reliability, as a function of cognitive demand.

title: Evidence of an optimal error rate for motor skill learning
abstract: When acquiring a motor skill, learners must practice skill at a difficulty that is challenging but still manageable to gradually improve their performance. In other words, during training, learner must experience success as well as failure. Does there exist an optimal proportion of successes and failures to promote fastest improvements in skill? Here, we build on a recent theoretical framework for optimal machine learning, extending it to the learning of motor skills. We then designed a custom task whose difficulty dynamically changed along with human subjects performance, constraining the error rate during training. In a large behavioral dataset (N=192), we observed evidence that learning is greatest at around a [~]30% error rate, matching our theoretical predictions.

title: Signatures of innovation and selection in extremotolerant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus
abstract: Organisms specialized to extreme environments can be product of millions of years of evolutionary engineering and refinement. The underlying genetics can be quite distinct from ones operating at earlier stages of trait innovation. In this work, we have developed multi-stress resistant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus, which diverged from its closest relative >20 million years ago, as a model for interspecies comparative biology and genomics. In growth assays of Kluyveromyces genus, we found that K. marxianus exhibited unique tolerance of high heat and a subset of chemical stress conditions. We then generated and analyzed omic profiles from across the genus to find molecular features associated with- and potentially causal for - K. marxianus traits. Expression profiling revealed divergent lipid processing and membrane transport programs in K. marxianus, borne out in changes in lipid utilization in experimental assays. Sequence analyses found robust evidence for expansions in gene families in K. marxianus genome, most notably among transmembrane transporters and in metabolic enzymes. In molecular-evolution tests, we identified adaptive protein variants throughout K. marxianus genome among which plasma membrane transporters were over-represented. These data enable a model of the molecular mechanisms and evolutionary pressures underlying K. marxianus traits, including adaptive changes to transporters, lipid processing, and membrane functions mediating stress resistance.

title: Alpha phase-coding supports feature binding during working memory maintenance
abstract: The ability to successfully retain and manipulate information in working memory (WM) requires that objects individual features are bound into cohesive representations; yet, mechanisms supporting feature binding remain unclear. Binding (or swap) errors, where memorized features are erroneously associated with wrong object, can provide a window into the intrinsic limits in capacity of WM that represent a key bottleneck in our cognitive ability. We tested hypothesis that binding in WM is accomplished via neural phase synchrony and that swap errors result from perturbations in this synchrony. Using magnetoencephalography data collected from human subjects in a task designed to induce swap errors, we showed that swaps are characterized by reduced phase-locked oscillatory activity during memory retention, as predicted by an attractor model of spiking neural networks. Further, we found that this reduction arises from increased phase coding variability in the alpha-band over a distributed network of sensorimotor areas. Our findings demonstrate that feature binding in WM is accomplished through phase coding dynamics that emerge from competition between different memories.

title: Organellomics: AI-driven deep organellar phenotyping reveals novel ALS mechanisms in human neurons
abstract: Systematic assessment of organelle architectures, termed organellome, offers valuable insights into cellular states and pathomechanisms, but remains largely uncharted. Here, we present a deep phenotypic learning based on vision transformers, resulting in Neuronal Organellomics Vision Atlas (NOVA) model that studies confocal images of more than 30 markers of distinct membrane-bound and membraneless organelles in 11.5 million images of human neurons. Organellomics analysis quantifies perturbation-induced changes in organelle localization and morphology using a rigorous mixed-effects meta-analytic framework that accounts for sampling variance and experimental heterogeneity. Applying this approach, we delineate phenotypic alterations in neurons carrying ALS-associated mutations and uncover a physical and functional crosstalk between cytoplasmic mislocalized TDP-43, a hallmark of ALS, and processing bodies (P-bodies), membraneless organelles regulating mRNA stability. These findings are validated in patient-derived neurons and human neuropathology. NOVA establishes a scalable framework for quantitative mapping of subcellular phenotypes and provides a new avenue for investigating the neurocellular basis of disease.

title: Prediction of protein-carbohydrate binding sites from protein primary sequence
abstract: BackgroundA protein is a large complex macromolecule that has a crucial role in performing most of the work in cells and tissues. It is made up of one or more long chains of amino acid residues. Another important biomolecule, after DNA and protein, is carbohydrate. Carbohydrates interact with proteins to run various biological processes. Several biochemical experiments exist to learn protein-carbohydrate interactions, but they are expensive, time-consuming, and challenging. Therefore, developing computational techniques for effectively predicting protein-carbohydrate binding interactions from protein primary sequence has given rise to a prominent new field of research.

title: Do eyes say it all? Assessing utility of physiological signals for predicting systemic cognitive states
abstract: Robust estimation of systemic human cognitive states is critical for many applications, from simply detecting inefficiencies in human task performance to adapting behaviors of artificial agents to improve team performance in mixed-initiative human-machine teams. Here we use comprehensive analyses of a multi-modal dataset from a multi-tasking driving experiment to provide systematic evidence that percentage change in pupil size (PCPS) in human eye gaze is the most reliable biomarker for assessing three human cognitive states relevant to task performance: workload, sense of urgency, and mind wandering. Specifically, we performed comprehensive statistical tests that establish the superior performance of PCPS compared other physiological signals like electroencephalogram (EEG), functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), respiration, arterial blood pressure (ABP), and skin conductance. Based on eye gaze data, we also characterized the relation between workload and sense of urgency, observing that consecutive occurrences of higher sense of urgency tended to increase overall workload. We also trained five state-of-the-art machine learning models on data to determine their potential for predicting three systemic cognitive states across subjects, showing that four of them had similar highest accuracy in cognitive state classification based on PCPS (with one, random forest, showing inferior performance). In combination with statistical analyses, comparative modeling results demonstrate that PCPS, in contrast to prior findings in literature, represents the optimal method for estimating three performance-relevant cognitive states.

title: Exploring the limits of pre-trained embeddings in machine-guided protein design: a case study on predicting AAV vector viability
abstract: Adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors are widely used for gene delivery in protein engineering applications. However, predicting AAV vector viability remains challenging due to the complex interplay between viral capsid proteins and host cell factors. This study explores the limitations of pre-trained protein language model embeddings in predicting AAV vector viability, using machine learning approaches to improve prediction accuracy. The results provide insights into the challenges of using pre-trained embeddings for protein design tasks and suggest directions for future research.

title: Conditional diffusion with locality-aware modal alignment for generating diverse protein conformations
abstract: Protein conformation generation is crucial for drug discovery and protein design. This paper presents a conditional diffusion model with locality-aware modal alignment for generating diverse protein conformations. The method combines the strengths of diffusion models and attention mechanisms to generate realistic protein structures with improved diversity and quality.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Science, Engineering, and Healthcare: Insights from UKâ€“Azerbaijan Collaboration
abstract: This paper explores the applications of artificial intelligence across science, engineering, and healthcare domains, with a focus on international collaboration between the UK and Azerbaijan. It discusses current trends, challenges, and future directions for AI research and applications.

title: BioStruct-Africa's scalable framework for AlphaFold-enabled research training and sustainable workforce development
abstract: AlphaFold has revolutionized protein structure prediction. This paper describes BioStruct-Africa's scalable framework for AlphaFold-enabled research training and sustainable workforce development in Africa. The framework aims to build capacity for protein structure prediction and related research across the continent.

title: Targeting signaling pathways in lymphoma: From molecular mechanisms to clinical breakthroughs
abstract: Lymphoma is a type of blood cancer that affects the lymphatic system. This paper reviews the signaling pathways involved in lymphoma and discusses how targeting these pathways can lead to clinical breakthroughs in treatment.

title: Physiological and Molecular Mechanisms of Nitrogen Regulation on Grain Quality in Cereal Crops at Large Scale
abstract: Nitrogen is a critical nutrient for plant growth and grain quality. This study investigates the physiological and molecular mechanisms of nitrogen regulation on grain quality in cereal crops at large scale, providing insights for improving crop yields and nutritional quality.

title: Keratinases: microbial sources, mechanisms, and industrial applications in waste valorization
abstract: Keratinases are enzymes that degrade keratin, a structural protein. This paper reviews microbial sources, mechanisms, and industrial applications of keratinases in waste valorization, highlighting their potential for sustainable waste management and resource recovery.

title: Aquatic biopeptides in flavor and metabolic regulation: A convergence of biochemistry and artificial intelligence
abstract: Biopeptides from aquatic sources have potential applications in flavor and metabolic regulation. This paper explores the convergence of biochemistry and artificial intelligence in studying aquatic biopeptides, discussing computational approaches for biopeptide discovery and characterization.

title: Real-Time Digital Micromotor Tracking-Enabled Ultrasensitive Immunoassay
abstract: Digital micromotors have emerged as powerful tools for biosensing and bioanalysis. This paper presents a real-time digital micromotor tracking-enabled ultrasensitive immunoassay for detecting biomolecules with high sensitivity and specificity.

title: Editorial: Exploration of the role of heme proteins in biology with experimental and computational methods
abstract: Heme proteins play crucial roles in various biological processes including oxygen transport, electron transfer, and catalysis. This editorial explores the role of heme proteins in biology with experimental and computational methods, highlighting recent advances and future directions.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Epidemic Modeling and Pandemic Preparedness: A Comprehensive Review
abstract: Artificial intelligence has become increasingly important in epidemic modeling and pandemic preparedness. This comprehensive review discusses AI applications in disease modeling, prediction, and response planning, highlighting strengths, limitations, and future research directions.
